text: Emilios Avgouleas is a Greek professor and researcher specialising in international financial markets and blockchain technology. He holds the chair in international banking law and finance at the University of Edinburgh.Staff profile at University of Edinburgh, School of Law. https://www.law.ed.ac.uk/people/professor-emilios-avgouleas Retrieved April 28, 2020Emilios Avgouleas's research while affiliated with the University of Edinburgh and other places, ResearchGate. https://www.researchgate.net/scientific- contributions/81014223_Emilios_Avgouleas Retrieved April 28, 2020 He is a member of the stakeholder group of the European Banking Authority as a 'top- ranking' academic.Members, Banking Stakeholder Group, European Banking Group. https://eba.europa.eu/about-us/organisation/banking-stakeholder-group/members. Retrieved April 29, 2020 He is also an independent member of the Euro-working group select panel for the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, which was set up to stabilize the Greek banking sector during the 2010 banking crisis. He is leading industry-linked projects using distributed ledger technology (DLT) to build markets for trading illiquid financial assets.Formation of selection panel announcement, Hellenic Financial Stability Fund. January 19, 2016. http://www.hfsf.gr/files/announcement_20160119_en.pdf == Education == Avgouleas graduated in law from the University of Athens, and in 1999 gained his doctorate in law and economics from the London School of Economics. ==Career== Avgouleas practised law as an associate at Clifford Chance and in investment banks. By 2000, he was a partner at Linklaters and then Tsibanoulis & Partners in Athens.IOHK Team. Retrieved April 23, 2020 from https://iohk.io/en/team/emilios-avgouleas In 2007, he switched into academia, taking up the post of professor of international financial markets and financial law at the University of Manchester.Manchester law school staff list (20 August 2011). Archived. https://web.archive.org/web/20110820084739/http://staffprofiles.humanities.manchester.ac.uk/StaffList.aspx?ou=I4074 Retrieved April 28, 2020 In 2012, he moved to the University of Edinburgh, as a professor of international banking. He is an associate director of the Edinburgh Centre for Commercial Law.People at the Edinburgh Centre for Commercial Law. https://www.law.ed.ac.uk/research/research-centres-and- networks/edinburgh-centre-commercial-law/people Retrieved April 28, 2020 He is also on the staff of Edinburgh University's blockchain technology lab Blockchain Technology Lab. https://www.ed.ac.uk/informatics/blockchain where he “develops models for the use of blockchain technology to lower transaction costs, enhance investor control over their investments and optimise risk management in financial markets”. People, Blockchain Technology Lab. https://btl.iohk.io/people. Retrieved April 28, 2020 He has written about the potential for blockchain technology “to transform the structure and future direction of the financial services industry”. Avgouleas, E and Kiayias, A (December 6, 2018) “The promise of blockchain technology for global securities and derivatives markets: the new financial ecosystem and the 'holy grail' of systemic risk containment”. Edinburgh School of Law Research Paper 2018/43. SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3297052 However, at a lecture to the Asian Institute of International Financial Law, Avgouleas also argued that blockchain technology was not yet advanced enough to answer the challenges of securities and derivatives trading and clearing, though a number of platforms showed promise. Avgouleas, E (May 3, 2018)“Securities and (derivatives?) trading and clearing in the era of blockchain: a glass half full!” Asian Institute of International Financial Law, Faculty of Law, University of Hong Kong. https://www.law.hku.hk/aiifl/securities-and-derivatives-trading-and- clearing-in-the-era-of-blockchain-a-glass-half-full-thur-3-may-1230-130-pm/ Avgouleas was called as an expert witness by the House of Lords select committee on the European Union for a 2012 report on MiFID II. “MiFID II: Getting it right for the City and EU financial services industry”, Lords select committee, UK Parliament. https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201213/ldselect/ldeucom/28/2804.htm Since 2015, he has been a member of the stakeholder group of the European Banking Authority as a ‘top-ranking' academic. Members, Banking Stakeholder Group, European Banking Group. https://eba.europa.eu/about- us/organisation/banking-stakeholder-group/members. Retrieved April 29, 2020 Visiting professorships include Yale, Harvard, National University of Singapore, Hong Kong University,Avgouleas, E (May 3, 2018)“Securities and (derivatives?) trading and clearing in the era of blockchain: a glass half full!” Asian Institute of International Financial Law, Faculty of Law, University of Hong Kong. https://www.law.hku.hk/aiifl/securities-and- derivatives-trading-and-clearing-in-the-era-of-blockchain-a-glass-half-full- thur-3-may-1230-130-pm/ Duke Law School, China University of Political Science and Law, and the Athens University of Economics and Business.IOHK Team. Retrieved April 23, 2020 from https://iohk.io/en/team/emilios-avgouleas On the issue of the coronavirus crisis, he has warned that if it lasts more than a few months, “Tens of millions of jobs could be lost despite trillions of dollars being spent on saving businesses and industries”.“Could the world be heading for another financial crisis?” (April 12, 2020) Al Jazeera. https://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/countingthecost/2020/04/world-heading- financial-crisis-200411130805012.html Retrieved April 28, 2020 Furthermore, it could be “the kiss of death for countries and the stability of their financial systems”. Legorano, G, Kowsmann, P, Patrick, M (14 April 2020) “The bank backstop: Can Europe's lenders weather the coronavirus crisis?” The Wall Street Journal, https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-bank-backstop-can-europes- lenders-weather-the-coronavirus-crisis-11586823073 (subscription needed). Retrieved April 28, 2020 ==Findings on the Greek banking crisis== Avgouleas was critical of early attempts to stabilize the Greek banking sector during the banking crisis after a bailout by the EU and IMF in 2010. In 2014, he delivered a paper on ethics and restoring confidence at a conference organised by the Hellenic Bank Association, Greece’s national banking trade group.Avgouleas, E, (May 23, 2014) “Ethics in the banking sector: restoring lost confidence”, delivered at “The Future of the European Banking Union” conference, Hellenic Bank Association. https://www.hba.gr/Events/UplFiles/ekdiloseis%20triton%20foreon/ERA_214D68_E_new.pdf That same year he published a “critical evaluation” of bank bail-in regimes with Charles Goodhart.Goodhart, C, and Avgouleas, E (August 11, 2014) “A critical evaluation of bail-ins as bank recapitalisation mechanisms”. SSRN: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2478647. Retrieved 29 April, 2020 In 2015, he described the disposal of banking assets as “a fire sale”,Avgouleas, E (November 25, 2015) “A Greek bank tragedy”, Greek Public Policy Forum. http://www.greekcrisis.net/2015/11/a-greek-bank-tragedy.html resulting in an “enormous loss” for Greek taxpayers.Koukakis, N (November 24, 2015) “The $400 billion ripoff that could destroy the Greek bailout”, CNBC.com. https://www.cnbc.com/2015/11/24/the-400-billion-ripoff-that-could-destroy-the- greek-bailout.html Avgouleas was appointed in January 2016 as an independent member of a selection and evaluation panel for board members of the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, and contributed to the interim and final financial reports.Formation of selection panel announcement, Hellenic Financial Stability Fund. January 19, 2016. http://www.hfsf.gr/files/announcement_20160119_en.pdfAnnual Financial Report, Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, July 2016. http://www.hfsf.gr/files/hfsf_annual_report_2015_en.pdfInterim Financial Report, Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, December 2016. http://www.hfsf.gr/files/HFSF_Interim_January_June_2016_en.pdf He returned to the issue of bank bail-ins with Goodhart at the end of the year.Goodhart, C, and Avgouleas, E (December 5, 2016) “An anatomy of bank bail-ins – why the eurozone needs a fiscal backstop for the banking sector”, in European Economy: Banks, Regulation, and the Real Sector. https://european-economy.eu/2016-2/an- anatomy-of-bank-bail-ins-why-the-eurozone-needs-a-fiscal-backstop-for-the- banking-sector/ In May 2018, he worked on a CEPR report that began: “A spectre continues to haunt Greece and no less its creditors.” It then discussed debt relief, and how schemes could be structured so as to provide the right incentives for budgetary discipline.Eichengreen, B, Avgouleas, E, et al (March 2018) “Independent report on the Greek official debt”, CEPR Policy Insight No 92. https://cepr.org/sites/default/files/policy_insights/PolicyInsight92.pdf He also contributed to a CEPR commentary that characterised Greece’s third economic programme as “unlike its two predecessors” in being “relatively successful”.Eichengreen, B, Avgouleas, E, et al (20 March 2018) “Putting the Greek debt problem to rest” Vox CEPR policy portal. https://voxeu.org/article/putting-greek-debt-problem-rest In late 2018, he said a “radical” move by the Greek central bank to buy up non-performing loans held by the country’s banks “has to be welcomed”.Hope, K (November 21, 2018) “Greek central bank aims to use lenders’ tax credits to fix bad debts”, Financial Times. https://www.ft.com/content/fcf224da- edac-11e8-8180-9cf212677a57 In a Financial Times article about addressing Greek bank debt, he pointed to a high level of non-performing loans compared with other EU member states. This came after “a long period of inertia by bank boards and regulatory authorities” as a result of “close relationships between politicians, bankers and favoured businessmen”.Hope, K (May 20, 2019) “Greek banks play long game on road to recovery”, Financial Times. https At the end of 2019, Avgouleas said that Greece needed infrastructure investment from China after 10 years of financial devastation: "Its stock of capital investment has to be replenished. The only available capital investors are the Chinese."Weihua, C (November 11, 2019) “Cooperation between China and Greece extends across subjects”, China Daily, global edition, p3. He contributed to an Oxford University blog post that discussed ways of avoiding bank bailouts and a “doom loop” from the public cost of funding such bailouts.Avgouleas, E, Nolan, C, and Tsoukalas, J (19 Dec 2019) “Designing an optimal banker’s tax to avert bank bailouts: rationales and objectives”. https://www.law.ox.ac.uk/business-law-blog/blog/2019/12/designing-optimal- bankers-tax-avert-bank-bailouts-rationales-and. The Promise of Blockchain Technology for Global Securities and Derivatives Markets: The New Financial Ecosystem and the ‘Holy Grail’ of Systemic Risk Containment. * Avgouleas, E, and Donald, DC, (eds) (2019) The Political Economy of Financial Regulation, Cambridge University Press. * Avgouleas, E (2018) Capital Markets Union in Europe, Oxford University Press. * Avgouleas, E (2012) Governance of Global Financial Markets: The Law, the Economics, the Politics, Cambridge University Press. * Avgouleas, E (2005) The Mechanics and Regulation of Market Abuse: A Legal and Economic Analysis, Oxford University Press. == References == Category:Greek economists Category:Economic crises in Europe Category:National and Kapodistrian University of Athens alumni Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics Category:University of Manchester Category:University of Edinburgh Category:Year of birth missing (living people) Category:Living people
